Prompt:
Read the following: More and more people use computers, but not everyone agrees that this benefits society. Those who support advances in technology believe that computers have a positive effect on people. They teach hand-eye coordination, give people the ability to learn about faraway places and people, and even allow people to talk online with other people. Others have different ideas. Some experts are concerned that people are spending too much time on their computers and less time exercising, enjoying nature, and interacting with family and friends. 

Write a letter to your local newspaper in which you state your opinion on the effects computers have on people. Persuade the readers to agree with you.
Response:
Dear editor,

I'm writing to express my opinion on the impact of computers on society. While some people believe that computers have a positive effect on people, others have concerns about the amount of time spent on them. As someone who has used computers for many years, I believe that they have both positive and negative effects.

On the positive side, computers have made it easier for people to access information and communicate with others. People can learn new things, connect with others, and share their ideas and experiences with the world. Computers have also opened up new opportunities for education, entertainment, and employment.

However, I also share the concerns of those who worry about the amount of time people spend on their computers. Spending too much time sitting in front of a screen can lead to health problems, such as obesity and eye strain. Moreover, excessive computer use can lead to social isolation and a decrease in face-to-face interactions with others.

In my opinion, the key to balancing the positive and negative effects of computers is moderation. People should use computers in a way that enhances their lives without taking away from other important activities. Parents should set limits on their children's computer use and encourage them to engage in outdoor activities and socialize with friends. Adults should also make an effort to balance their computer time with exercise, socializing, and other activities that promote physical and mental well-being.

In conclusion, while computers have both positive and negative effects on society, I believe that they can be a valuable tool when used in moderation. It's up to us as individuals and as a society to ensure that we use technology in a way that enhances our lives without negatively impacting our health and relationships.

Sincerely,
[Your name]

Response:
Dear editor,

As someone who has grown up in the era of technology, I have seen firsthand the impact that computers can have on people. While some argue that computers are a positive force, I believe that they have a negative effect on society.

Firstly, computers can be a distraction. With the constant availability of the internet, social media, and games, people are spending more and more time in front of a screen and less time engaging in physical activity, spending time with family and friends, or exploring the world around them. This can lead to a sedentary lifestyle, which has been linked to a range of health problems, including obesity, diabetes, and heart disease.

Furthermore, computers can also have a negative impact on mental health. Social media, in particular, can create unrealistic expectations and promote comparison and competition. People are constantly comparing their lives to the curated highlight reels of others, leading to feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem. Additionally, the constant stream of information and notifications can be overwhelming and contribute to stress and anxiety.

Finally, computers can also have a negative impact on our relationships. While technology can connect us with people across the world, it can also make us more isolated. People are spending more time interacting with their screens than with real-life human beings, leading to a decline in face-to-face communication skills and empathy.

In conclusion, while computers can have some benefits, such as access to information and education, I believe that the negative effects outweigh the positive. I urge readers to be mindful of their computer use and to make an effort to disconnect from technology and engage with the world around them.

Sincerely,
[Your Name].

Prompt:
"All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." --Katherine Paterson, Author
Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your vies on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? Support your position with convincing arguments from your own experience, observations, and/or reading.
Response:
Dear Editor,

As a frequent visitor to my local library, I have often found myself pondering the issue of censorship in libraries. Should certain materials be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? It is a question that has sparked heated debates among book lovers and free speech advocates. In my opinion, censorship in libraries is a slippery slope that should be avoided.

First and foremost, censorship undermines the fundamental principle of intellectual freedom. Libraries are meant to be bastions of knowledge and learning, where individuals can explore new ideas and perspectives without fear of censorship or judgment. By removing materials from the shelves, libraries are effectively limiting the scope of information available to the public, and thereby stifling intellectual curiosity.

Moreover, censorship can often be arbitrary and subjective. What one person finds offensive, another person might find insightful or thought-provoking. It is impossible to create a universally acceptable standard for what materials should be banned, as people's tastes and values differ vastly. Libraries should not be in the business of dictating what people should or should not read, watch, or listen to.

Furthermore, censorship can have a chilling effect on free speech and artistic expression. When libraries remove materials from their shelves, they are essentially silencing the voices of authors, artists, and creators who have the right to express themselves freely. By censoring certain materials, libraries are inadvertently promoting a culture of fear and conformity, where dissenting voices are marginalized and ignored.

Another argument against censorship in libraries is that it can often be ineffective. In today's digital age, information is readily available online, and individuals can easily access materials that have been banned or censored. By removing materials from library shelves, libraries are not solving the problem of offensive content; they are merely driving people to seek out information from other, potentially less reliable sources.

Finally, censorship in libraries can have a disproportionate impact on marginalized communities. Libraries play a vital role in providing access to information and resources for people who may not have the means to access them otherwise. By censoring materials that may be of particular interest or relevance to marginalized communities, libraries are inadvertently perpetuating systemic inequalities and limiting opportunities for social mobility.

In conclusion, censorship in libraries is a dangerous precedent that undermines the fundamental principles of intellectual freedom, artistic expression, and equal access to information. Libraries should not be in the business of censoring materials, but rather in the business of providing access to a wide range of perspectives and ideas. By embracing diversity and inclusivity, libraries can foster a culture of open-mindedness and critical thinking, where individuals can engage in meaningful dialogue and explore new ideas without fear of censorship or reprisal.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

Firstly, censorship can be a slippery slope. Once we begin removing materials that are deemed offensive, it becomes increasingly difficult to determine what should be allowed and what should be banned. This can lead to a situation where certain groups or individuals are able to impose their beliefs and values on others, stifling diversity and freedom of expression.

This can lead to a lack of representation and inclusivity, and can perpetuate systemic inequalities.

By doing so, we can foster a society that is open-minded, tolerant, and culturally rich.

The ability to access and consume a wide range of ideas and perspectives is essential to a healthy democracy, as it allows individuals to form informed opinions and engage in meaningful discourse. Prompt:
"All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf -- that work I abhor -- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us." --Katherine Paterson, Author
Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your vies on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? Support your position with convincing arguments from your own experience, observations, and/or reading.
Response:
Dear Editor,
As a frequent library user, I've often encountered materials that I find offensive or inappropriate. It's natural to wonder whether such materials should be removed from the shelves. However, I strongly believe that censorship has no place in libraries.

First and foremost, censorship goes against the fundamental purpose of a library, which is to provide access to knowledge and information. Libraries are meant to be a hub of free expression, where people can explore different perspectives and ideas without fear of judgment or censorship. When we start removing materials that are deemed offensive, we undermine this fundamental principle.

Moreover, the definition of what is offensive varies widely from person to person. What one person finds objectionable, another might find valuable or even essential. For instance, a book that deals with mature themes like sexuality, violence, or racism might be considered offensive by some, but it might also be a lifeline for someone who is grappling with those issues. By leaving such materials on the shelves, we are not endorsing their content, but rather acknowledging the diversity of our patrons and their needs.

Furthermore, censorship can have unintended consequences. When we remove materials from the shelves, we run the risk of creating a culture of fear and suspicion. Patrons might become hesitant to explore certain topics or authors, for fear of being judged or censored. Librarians might become reluctant to acquire new materials, lest they be accused of promoting offensive content. This chilling effect can stifle intellectual curiosity and stunt the growth of knowledge.

It's also worth noting that censorship can be a slippery slope. Once we start removing materials that are deemed offensive, it's hard to draw the line. Who gets to decide what's offensive and what's not? What criteria do we use to make such decisions? Before long, we might find ourselves in a situation where entire sections of the library are empty, because some group or another has taken offense to their contents.

Of course, there are situations where materials might need to be removed from the shelves, such as when they are factually inaccurate, promote hate speech, or violate copyright laws. However, such cases should be rare and should be decided on a case-by-case basis, with careful consideration and input from diverse stakeholders.

In conclusion, while I understand the impulse to remove offensive materials from library shelves, I believe that censorship has no place in libraries. By leaving materials available, we are not endorsing their content, but rather upholding the values of free expression, diversity, and intellectual curiosity. Let us keep our libraries free and open, and trust our patrons to navigate the rich and complex world of ideas with discernment and respect.

Sincerely,
[Your Name]

However, the removal of certain materials based on their offensiveness can be problematic, as it can lead to a form of cultural policing that restricts access to information and stifles intellectual freedom.

One argument against censorship in libraries is that it can limit the diversity of perspectives and ideas available to patrons. Libraries are meant to be inclusive spaces that provide access to a wide range of materials, including those that may be considered controversial or offensive. By removing certain materials, libraries may inadvertently create an echo chamber where patrons are only exposed to a narrow range of viewpoints, rather than being exposed to a diverse array of perspectives that challenge their beliefs and foster critical thinking.

Another argument against censorship is that it can be used as a tool of oppression. The essay "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" describes a challenging bicycle ride along a rugged terrain. The setting of the ride has a significant impact on the cyclist, presenting various obstacles and challenges that require careful navigation.

Firstly, the essay highlights the issue of potholes, which are a common feature of the road. These potholes can be treacherous for cyclists, as they can cause sudden jolts and jarring that can throw the rider off balance. The essay notes that "the potholes were so deep and frequent that it was like riding through a minefield." This quote emphasizes the danger posed by the potholes and the need for the cyclist to be vigilant and cautious.

Secondly, the essay mentions the problem of debris on the road, including broken glass, nails, and other hazards. This debris can cause punctures and other damage to the bicycle, which can leave the cyclist stranded. The essay notes that "the road was littered with broken glass and nails, making it difficult to avoid getting a flat tire." This quote highlights the challenges of navigating a road with debris and the need for the cyclist to be constantly aware of the road surface.

Thirdly, the essay describes the issue of steep inclines and declines. The steep hills require the cyclist to expend more energy and control their speed carefully. The essay notes that "the hills were so steep that it felt like climbing a mountain." This quote emphasizes the physical demands of navigating steep hills and the need for the cyclist to be in good physical condition.

Finally, the essay mentions the problem of narrow roads with no shoulder. This makes it difficult for the cyclist to avoid obstacles and maintain a safe distance from traffic. The essay notes that "the road was so narrow that it was like riding through a tunnel." This quote highlights the challenges of navigating a road with limited space and the need for the cyclist to be alert and cautious.

In conclusion, the features of the setting in the essay "ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" significantly affect the cyclist. The potholes, debris, steep inclines, and narrow roads with no shoulder all pose challenges that require careful navigation and vigilance. The cyclist must be cautious, physically fit, and alert to avoid obstacles and maintain a safe distance from traffic.

This type of terrain can be challenging for cyclists, as it requires them to maintain control of their bicycle while navigating difficult turns and inclines. The narrowness of the road also means that cyclists may encounter oncoming traffic, which can increase the risk of accidents.

Finally, the essay mentions that the road is located in a remote area with limited services and support. This means that if a cyclist experiences a mechanical issue or an accident, they may have to rely on their own resources to repair or recover their bicycle. This highlights the importance of self-sufficiency and preparation for cyclists embarking on long-distance journeys in remote areas.

In conclusion, the features of the setting in "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" significantly affect the cyclist's experience. The road surface quality, presence of gravel and debris, narrow and winding terrain, and remote location all pose challenges and hazards that cyclists must be aware of and prepared for. By understanding these factors, cyclists can better navigate the route and ensure their safety.

Response:

Firstly, the hills on the road make it difficult for cyclists to maintain a consistent speed. Secondly, the winding nature of the road makes it difficult for cyclists to maintain a straight line and maintain their balance. This can be particularly challenging for inexperienced cyclists or those who are not comfortable with tight turns.

Lastly, the posted speed limit of 30 mph further complicates the situation for cyclists. The essay notes that "the speed limit was strictly enforced," which means that cyclists must be mindful of their speed and avoid exceeding the limit. In conclusion, the features of the setting in "Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" greatly affect the cyclist's experience. The hilly and winding road, combined with the strict speed limit, present a challenging environment for cyclists that requires physical effort, balance, and careful speed management.

Prompt:
Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased.
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion.
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy potted plant by the corner. There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered.
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the bucket.
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel.
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs.
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it. “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.”
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it.
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her.
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind.
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?”
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question.
“How much?”
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins.
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .”
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said.
“Then what else—?”
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.”
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes.
“What happened?” she asked, more gently.
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said.
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.”
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled.
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said.
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.”
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.”
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her.
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?”
“I’d love it,” Saeng said.
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.
“Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, copyright © 1993 by Minfong Ho, from Join In, Multiethnic Short Stories, by Donald R. Gallo, ed.
Read the last paragraph of the story.
"When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.
Response:
The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to take the driver's test again in the spring when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding because it highlights Saeng's determination and resilience. Throughout the story, Saeng has been struggling with the loss of her old life in Vietnam and the challenges of adapting to a new culture in America. Her failure to pass the driver's test is a symbol of her struggles to navigate this new world.

However, by the end of the story, Saeng has found a sense of comfort and familiarity in the "winter hibiscus" plant, which reminds her of her childhood home in Vietnam. The plant becomes a symbol of hope and renewal for Saeng, representing her ability to bloom and thrive even in the harshest of environments.

By concluding the story with Saeng's vow to take the test again, the author suggests that Saeng has found the strength and determination to overcome her struggles and succeed in her new life. The image of the geese returning and the hibiscus budding also implies a sense of cyclical renewal, suggesting that Saeng will continue to grow and flourish as the seasons change.

Moreover, the author's use of sensory details and imagery throughout the story helps to create a vivid picture of Saeng's emotional journey. For example, the description of the "winter hibiscus" plant as a "hot, moist world exploding with greenery" echoes Saeng's own feelings of being overwhelmed by her new surroundings. Similarly, the image of the geese flying overhead, their "faint honks clear and—yes—familiar" to Saeng, suggests a sense of longing and nostalgia for her old life.

Overall, the author's conclusion emphasizes Saeng's resilience and determination to succeed in her new life, while also highlighting the ongoing challenges and emotions that she will continue to face as she navigates this unfamiliar world.

The use of language and imagery suggests a sense of hope and renewal, indicating that Saeng is ready to embrace her new life and move forward with purpose.

Prompt:
Winter Hibiscus by Minfong Ho
Saeng, a teenage girl, and her family have moved to the United States from Vietnam. As Saeng walks home after failing her driver’s test, she sees a familiar plant. Later, she goes to a florist shop to see if the plant can be purchased.
It was like walking into another world. A hot, moist world exploding with greenery. Huge flat leaves, delicate wisps of tendrils, ferns and fronds and vines of all shades and shapes grew in seemingly random profusion.
“Over there, in the corner, the hibiscus. Is that what you mean?” The florist pointed at a leafy potted plant by the corner. There, in a shaft of the wan afternoon sunlight, was a single blood-red blossom, its five petals splayed back to reveal a long stamen tipped with yellow pollen. Saeng felt a shock of recognition so intense, it was almost visceral.1
“Saebba,” Saeng whispered.
A saebba hedge, tall and lush, had surrounded their garden, its lush green leaves dotted with vermilion flowers. And sometimes after a monsoon rain, a blossom or two would have blown into the well, so that when she drew the well water, she would find a red blossom floating in the bucket.
Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel.
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs.
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it. “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.”
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it.
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her.
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind.
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?”
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question.
“How much?”
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins.
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .”
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said.
“Then what else—?”
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.”
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes.
“What happened?” she asked, more gently.
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said.
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.”
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled.
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said.
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.”
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.”
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her.
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?”
“I’d love it,” Saeng said.
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.
“Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, copyright © 1993 by Minfong Ho, from Join In, Multiethnic Short Stories, by Donald R. Gallo, ed.
Read the last paragraph of the story.
"When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.
Response:
The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to take the driver's test again in the spring when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding because it symbolizes Saeng's determination to overcome her struggles and find a sense of belonging in her new home. Throughout the story, Saeng has been struggling to adjust to life in the United States, feeling disconnected from her roots and culture. The hibiscus plant, which she recognizes from her childhood in Vietnam, becomes a symbol of her connection to her past and her desire to hold onto her cultural identity.

By concluding the story with Saeng's vow to take the test again, the author suggests that Saeng has found a sense of purpose and determination to overcome her struggles. The image of the geese returning and the hibiscus budding also implies a sense of renewal and new beginnings, which fits with Saeng's determination to try again.

Furthermore, the author has used the imagery of the hibiscus plant and the geese throughout the story to convey Saeng's emotions and sense of belonging. For example, when Saeng sees the hibiscus plant in the florist shop, she feels a "shock of recognition" and a sense of connection to her past. Similarly, when she watches the geese fly overhead, she feels a sense of familiarity and comfort. By using these images again at the end of the story, the author reinforces the idea that Saeng has found a sense of belonging and connection to her new home.

Overall, the conclusion of the story suggests that Saeng has found a way to reconcile her past and present, and that she is determined to move forward and find success in her new home. The use of the hibiscus plant and the geese as symbols of Saeng's connection to her past and her determination to succeed adds depth and meaning to the story, and reinforces the theme of identity and belonging.

Slowly, Saeng walked down the narrow aisle toward the hibiscus. Orchids, lanna bushes, oleanders, elephant ear begonias, and bougainvillea vines surrounded her. Plants that she had not even realized she had known but had forgotten drew her back into her childhood world.
When she got to the hibiscus, she reached out and touched a petal gently. It felt smooth and cool, with a hint of velvet toward the center—just as she had known it would feel.
And beside it was yet another old friend, a small shrub with waxy leaves and dainty flowers with purplish petals and white centers. “Madagascar periwinkle,” its tag announced. How strange to see it in a pot, Saeng thought. Back home it just grew wild, jutting out from the cracks in brick walls or between tiled roofs.
And that rich, sweet scent—that was familiar, too. Saeng scanned the greenery around her and found a tall, gangly plant with exquisite little white blossoms on it. “Dok Malik,” she said, savoring the feel of the word on her tongue, even as she silently noted the English name on its tag, “jasmine.”
One of the blossoms had fallen off, and carefully Saeng picked it up and smelled it. She closed her eyes and breathed in, deeply. The familiar fragrance filled her lungs, and Saeng could almost feel the light strands of her grandmother’s long gray hair, freshly washed, as she combed it out with the fine-toothed buffalo-horn comb. And when the sun had dried it, Saeng would help the gnarled old fingers knot the hair into a bun, then slip a dok Malik bud into it.
Saeng looked at the white bud in her hand now, small and fragile. Gently, she closed her palm around it and held it tight. That, at least, she could hold on to. But where was the fine-toothed comb? The hibiscus hedge? The well? Her gentle grandmother? A wave of loss so deep and strong that it stung Saeng’s eyes now swept over her. A blink, a channel switch, a boat ride into the night, and it was all gone. Irretrievably, irrevocably gone.
And in the warm moist shelter of the greenhouse, Saeng broke down and wept.
It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her.
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind.
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?”
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question.
“How much?”
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins.
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .”
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said.
“Then what else—?”
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.”
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes.
“What happened?” she asked, more gently.
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said.
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.”
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled.
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said.
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.”
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.”
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her.
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?”
“I’d love it,” Saeng said.
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.
“Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, copyright © 1993 by Minfong Ho, from Join In, Multiethnic Short Stories, by Donald R. Gallo, ed.
Read the last paragraph of the story.
"When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Write a response that explains why the author concludes the story with this paragraph. In your response, include details and examples from the story that support your ideas.
Response:
The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to take the driver's test again in the spring because it highlights her determination and resilience. Throughout the story, Saeng struggles with the loss of her old life in Vietnam and the challenges of adapting to a new culture in America. However, when she sees the familiar plant, the "winter hibiscus," she feels a sense of comfort and belonging. This prompts her to buy the plant and plant it in her mother's garden, which symbolizes her desire to hold onto her roots while still embracing her new life.

By concluding the story with Saeng's vow to take the test again, the author shows that Saeng has found the strength and motivation to keep trying, despite her setbacks. This also underscores the idea that the process of adaptation and growth is ongoing, and that it requires effort and perseverance.

Furthermore, the use of the phrase "when they come back" suggests that Saeng is not only determined to pass the test but also to reconnect with her past and her cultural heritage. This echoes the theme of the story, which highlights the importance of preserving one's cultural identity while adapting to a new environment.

Overall, the conclusion of the story emphasizes Saeng's resilience and determination, while also underscoring the themes of cultural identity and adaptation. It provides a sense of closure and hope for Saeng's future, while also leaving the reader with a sense of Saeng's ongoing journey towards self-discovery and growth.

It was already dusk when Saeng reached home. The wind was blowing harder, tearing off the last remnants of green in the chicory weeds that were growing out of the cracks in the sidewalk. As if oblivious to the cold, her mother was still out in the vegetable garden, digging up the last of the onions with a rusty trowel. She did not see Saeng until the girl had quietly knelt down next to her.
Her smile of welcome warmed Saeng. “Ghup ma laio le? You’re back?” she said cheerfully. “Goodness, it’s past five. What took you so long? How did it go? Did you—?” Then she noticed the potted plant that Saeng was holding, its leaves quivering in the wind.
Mrs. Panouvong uttered a small cry of surprise and delight. “Dok faeng-noi!” she said. “Where did you get it?”
“I bought it,” Saeng answered, dreading her mother’s next question.
“How much?”
For answer Saeng handed her mother some coins.
“That’s all?” Mrs. Panouvong said, appalled, “Oh, but I forgot! You and the
Lambert boy ate Bee-Maags . . . .”
“No, we didn’t, Mother,” Saeng said.
“Then what else—?”
“Nothing else. I paid over nineteen dollars for it.”
“You what?” Her mother stared at her incredulously. “But how could you? All the seeds for this vegetable garden didn’t cost that much! You know how much we—” She paused, as she noticed the tearstains on her daughter’s cheeks and her puffy eyes.
“What happened?” she asked, more gently.
“I—I failed the test,” Saeng said.
For a long moment Mrs. Panouvong said nothing. Saeng did not dare look her mother in the eye. Instead, she stared at the hibiscus plant and nervously tore off a leaf, shredding it to bits.
Her mother reached out and brushed the fragments of green off Saeng’s hands. “It’s a beautiful plant, this dok faeng-noi,” she finally said. “I’m glad you got it.”
“It’s—it’s not a real one,” Saeng mumbled.
“I mean, not like the kind we had at—at—” She found that she was still too shaky to say the words at home, lest she burst into tears again. “Not like the kind we had before,” she said.
“I know,” her mother said quietly. “I’ve seen this kind blooming along the lake. Its flowers aren’t as pretty, but it’s strong enough to make it through the cold months here, this winter hibiscus. That’s what matters.”
She tipped the pot and deftly eased the ball of soil out, balancing the rest of the plant in her other hand. “Look how root-bound it is, poor thing,” she said. “Let’s plant it, right now.”
She went over to the corner of the vegetable patch and started to dig a hole in the ground. The soil was cold and hard, and she had trouble thrusting the shovel into it. Wisps of her gray hair trailed out in the breeze, and her slight frown deepened the wrinkles around her eyes. There was a frail, wiry beauty to her that touched Saeng deeply.
“Here, let me help, Mother,” she offered, getting up and taking the shovel away from her.
Mrs. Panouvong made no resistance. “I’ll bring in the hot peppers and bitter melons, then, and start dinner. How would you like an omelet with slices of the bitter melon?”
“I’d love it,” Saeng said.
Left alone in the garden, Saeng dug out a hole and carefully lowered the “winter hibiscus” into it. She could hear the sounds of cooking from the kitchen now, the beating of eggs against a bowl, the sizzle of hot oil in the pan. The pungent smell of bitter melon wafted out, and Saeng’s mouth watered. It was a cultivated taste, she had discovered—none of her classmates or friends, not even Mrs. Lambert, liked it—this sharp, bitter melon that left a golden aftertaste on the tongue. But she had grown up eating it and, she admitted to herself, much preferred it to a Big Mac.
The “winter hibiscus” was in the ground now, and Saeng tamped down the soil around it. Overhead, a flock of Canada geese flew by, their faint honks clear and—yes—familiar to Saeng now. Almost reluctantly, she realized that many of the things that she had thought of as strange before had become, through the quiet repetition of season upon season, almost familiar to her now. Like the geese. She lifted her head and watched as their distinctive V was etched against the evening sky, slowly fading into the distance.
When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again.
“Winter Hibiscus” by Minfong Ho, copyright © 1993 by Minfong Ho, from Join In, Multiethnic Short Stories, by Donald R. Gallo, ed.
Read the last paragraph of the story.
"When they come back, Saeng vowed silently to herself, in the spring, when the snows melt and the geese return and this hibiscus is budding, then I will take that test again." Response:
The author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to take the driver's test again in the spring when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding because it symbolizes Saeng's determination to overcome her struggles and find a sense of belonging in her new home. Throughout the story, Saeng has been struggling to adjust to life in the United States, feeling like an outsider and failing her driver's test. However, when she sees the familiar plant, the winter hibiscus, she feels a sense of connection to her past and her culture.

The author uses the imagery of the hibiscus and the geese to convey Saeng's emotions and journey. The hibiscus is a symbol of Saeng's roots and her connection to her homeland, while the geese represent the migrations and changes that she has experienced. By vowing to take the test again when the geese return and the hibiscus is budding, Saeng is indicating that she is ready to embrace her new life and overcome the challenges that she has faced.

Furthermore, the use of the word "when" in Saeng's vow implies a sense of hope and optimism for the future. The author is suggesting that Saeng has found a sense of purpose and determination, and that she will be able to overcome her struggles and succeed in her new home.

In conclusion, the author concludes the story with Saeng's vow to take the driver's test again in the spring because it symbolizes Saeng's determination to overcome her struggles and find a sense of belonging in her new home. Prompt:
Read the following:  When the Empire State Building was conceived, it was planned as the world’s tallest building, taller even than the new Chrysler Building that was being constructed at Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue in New York. At seventy-seven stories, it was the tallest building before the Empire State began construction, and Al Smith was determined to outstrip it in height.
The architect building the Chrysler Building, however, had a trick up his sleeve. He secretly constructed a 185-foot spire inside the building, and then shocked the public and the media by hoisting it up to the top of the Chrysler Building, bringing it to a height of 1,046 feet, 46 feet taller than the originally announced height of the Empire State Building.
Al Smith realized that he was close to losing the title of world’s tallest building, and on December 11, 1929, he announced that the Empire State would now reach the height of 1,250 feet. He would add a top or a hat to the building that would be even more distinctive than any other building in the city. John Tauranac describes the plan:
[The top of the Empire State Building] would be more than ornamental, more than a spire or dome or a pyramid put there to add a desired few feet to the height of the building or to mask something as mundane as a water tank. Their top, they said, would serve a higher calling. The Empire State Building would be equipped for an age of transportation that was then only the dream of aviation pioneers.
This dream of the aviation pioneers was travel by dirigible, or zeppelin, and the Empire State Building was going to have a mooring mast at its top for docking these new airships, which would accommodate passengers on already existing transatlantic routes and new routes that were yet to come.
The Age of Dirigibles
By the 1920s, dirigibles were being hailed as the transportation of the future. Also known today as blimps, dirigibles were actually enormous steel-framed balloons, with envelopes of cotton fabric filled with hydrogen and helium to make them lighter than air. Unlike a balloon, a dirigible could be maneuvered by the use of propellers and rudders, and passengers could ride in the gondola, or enclosed compartment, under the balloon.
Dirigibles had a top speed of eighty miles per hour, and they could cruise at seventy miles per hour for thousands of miles without needing refueling. Some were as long as one thousand feet, the same length as four blocks in New York City. The one obstacle to their expanded use in New York City was the lack of a suitable landing area. Al Smith saw an opportunity for his Empire State Building: A mooring mast added to the top of the building would allow dirigibles to anchor there for several hours for refueling or service, and to let passengers off and on. Dirigibles were docked by means of an electric winch, which hauled in a line from the front of the ship and then tied it to a mast. The body of the dirigible could swing in the breeze, and yet passengers could safely get on and off the dirigible by walking down a gangplank to an open observation platform.
The architects and engineers of the Empire State Building consulted with experts, taking tours of the equipment and mooring operations at the U.S. Naval Air Station in Lakehurst, New Jersey. The navy was the leader in the research and development of dirigibles in the United States. The navy even offered its dirigible, the Los Angeles, to be used in testing the mast. The architects also met with the president of a recently formed airship transport company that planned to offer dirigible service across the Pacific Ocean.
When asked about the mooring mast, Al Smith commented:
[It’s] on the level, all right. No kidding. We’re working on the thing now. One set of engineers here in New York is trying to dope out a practical, workable arrangement and the Government people in Washington are figuring on some safe way of mooring airships to this mast.
Designing the Mast
The architects could not simply drop a mooring mast on top of the Empire State Building’s flat roof. A thousand-foot dirigible moored at the top of the building, held by a single cable tether, would add stress to the building’s frame. The stress of the dirigible’s load and the wind pressure would have to be transmitted all the way to the building’s foundation, which was nearly eleven hundred feet below. The steel frame of the Empire State Building would have to be modified and strengthened to accommodate this new situation. Over sixty thousand dollars’ worth of modifications had to be made to the building’s framework.
Rather than building a utilitarian mast without any ornamentation, the architects designed a shiny glass and chrome-nickel stainless steel tower that would be illuminated from inside, with a stepped-back design that imitated the overall shape of the building itself. The rocket-shaped mast would have four wings at its corners, of shiny aluminum, and would rise to a conical roof that would house the mooring arm. The winches and control machinery for the dirigible mooring would be housed in the base of the shaft itself, which also housed elevators and stairs to bring passengers down to the eighty-sixth floor, where baggage and ticket areas would be located.
The building would now be 102 floors, with a glassed-in observation area on the 101st floor and an open observation platform on the 102nd floor. This observation area was to double as the boarding area for dirigible passengers.
Once the architects had designed the mooring mast and made changes to the existing plans for the building’s skeleton, construction proceeded as planned. When the building had been framed to the 85th floor, the roof had to be completed before the framing for the mooring mast could take place. The mast also had a skeleton of steel and was clad in stainless steel with glass windows. Two months after the workers celebrated framing the entire building, they were back to raise an American flag again—this time at the top of the frame for the mooring mast.
The Fate of the Mast
The mooring mast of the Empire State Building was destined to never fulfill its purpose, for reasons that should have been apparent before it was ever constructed. The greatest reason was one of safety: Most dirigibles from outside of the United States used hydrogen rather than helium, and hydrogen is highly flammable. When the German dirigible Hindenburg was destroyed by fire in Lakehurst, New Jersey, on May 6, 1937, the owners of the Empire State Building realized how much worse that accident could have been if it had taken place above a densely populated area such as downtown New York.
The greatest obstacle to the successful use of the mooring mast was nature itself. The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents. Even if the dirigible were tethered to the mooring mast, the back of the ship would swivel around and around the mooring mast. Dirigibles moored in open landing fields could be weighted down in the back with lead weights, but using these at the Empire State Building, where they would be dangling high above pedestrians on the street, was neither practical nor safe.
The other practical reason why dirigibles could not moor at the Empire State Building was an existing law against airships flying too low over urban areas. This law would make it illegal for a ship to ever tie up to the building or even approach the area, although two dirigibles did attempt to reach the building before the entire idea was dropped. In December 1930, the U.S. Navy dirigible Los Angeles approached the mooring mast but could not get close enough to tie up because of forceful winds. Fearing that the wind would blow the dirigible onto the sharp spires of other buildings in the area, which would puncture the dirigible’s shell, the captain could not even take his hands off the control levers. 
Two weeks later, another dirigible, the Goodyear blimp Columbia, attempted a publicity stunt where it would tie up and deliver a bundle of newspapers to the Empire State Building. Because the complete dirigible mooring equipment had never been installed, a worker atop the mooring mast would have to catch the bundle of papers on a rope dangling from the blimp. The papers were delivered in this fashion, but after this stunt the idea of using the mooring mast was shelved. In February 1931, Irving Clavan of the building’s architectural office said, “The as yet unsolved problems of mooring air ships to a fixed mast at such a height made it desirable to postpone to a later date the final installation of the landing gear.”
By the late 1930s, the idea of using the mooring mast for dirigibles and their passengers had quietly disappeared. Dirigibles, instead of becoming the transportation of the future, had given way to airplanes. The rooms in the Empire State Building that had been set aside for the ticketing and baggage of dirigible passengers were made over into the world’s highest soda fountain and tea garden for use by the sightseers who flocked to the observation decks. The highest open observation deck, intended for disembarking passengers, has never been open to the public.
Based on the excerpt, describe the obstacles the builders of the Empire State Building faced in attempting to allow dirigibles to dock there. Support your answer with relevant and specific information from the excerpt.
Response:
The builders of the Empire State Building faced several obstacles in their attempt to allow dirigibles to dock at the building's mooring mast. According to the excerpt, the greatest obstacle was safety concerns. Most dirigibles used hydrogen, which is highly flammable, and the risk of a fire accident was too great to ignore, especially after the Hindenburg disaster in 1937.

Another obstacle was the wind conditions on top of the building. The winds were constantly shifting due to violent air currents, making it difficult to securely moor a dirigible to the mast. Even if the dirigible were tethered to the mast, the back of the ship would swivel around and around the mooring mast, making it difficult to maintain a stable connection.

Additionally, there was an existing law against airships flying too low over urban areas, which would have made it illegal for a dirigible to tie up to the building or even approach the area. This law, combined with the safety concerns and wind conditions, made it impractical and unsafe to use the mooring mast for dirigibles.

Finally, the incomplete dirigible mooring equipment was another obstacle. The complete equipment was never installed, and a worker atop the mooring mast would have to catch a bundle of papers on a rope dangling from the blimp, which was not a reliable or safe method for mooring a dirigible.

Overall, the builders of the Empire State Building faced significant obstacles in their attempt to allow dirigibles to dock at the building's mooring mast, including safety concerns, wind conditions, legal restrictions, and incomplete equipment. These obstacles ultimately led to the idea being shelved and the mooring mast being used for other purposes.

By the 1920s, dirigibles were being hailed as the transportation of the future. The architects also met with the president of a recently formed airship transport company that planned to offer dirigible service across the Pacific Ocean.

This law would make it illegal for a ship to ever tie up to the building or even approach the area, although two dirigibles did attempt to reach the building before the entire idea was dropped. In December 1930, the U.S. Navy dirigible Los Angeles approached the mooring mast but could not get close enough to tie up because of forceful winds. Fearing that the wind would blow the dirigible onto the sharp spires of other buildings in the area, which would puncture the dirigible’s shell, the captain could not even take his hands off the control levers. 
Two weeks later, another dirigible, the Goodyear blimp Columbia, attempted a publicity stunt where it would tie up and deliver a bundle of newspapers to the Empire State Building. Because the complete dirigible mooring equipment had never been installed, a worker atop the mooring mast would have to catch the bundle of papers on a rope dangling from the blimp. The papers were delivered in this fashion, but after this stunt the idea of using the mooring mast was shelved. In February 1931, Irving Clavan of the building’s architectural office said, “The as yet unsolved problems of mooring air ships to a fixed mast at such a height made it desirable to postpone to a later date the final installation of the landing gear.”
By the late 1930s, the idea of using the mooring mast for dirigibles and their passengers had quietly disappeared. Dirigibles, instead of becoming the transportation of the future, had given way to airplanes. The rooms in the Empire State Building that had been set aside for the ticketing and baggage of dirigible passengers were made over into the world’s highest soda fountain and tea garden for use by the sightseers who flocked to the observation decks. The highest open observation deck, intended for disembarking passengers, has never been open to the public.

Prompt:
Read the following:  When the Empire State Building was conceived, it was planned as the world’s tallest building, taller even than the new Chrysler Building that was being constructed at Forty-second Street and Lexington Avenue in New York. At seventy-seven stories, it was the tallest building before the Empire State began construction, and Al Smith was determined to outstrip it in height.
The architect building the Chrysler Building, however, had a trick up his sleeve. He secretly constructed a 185-foot spire inside the building, and then shocked the public and the media by hoisting it up to the top of the Chrysler Building, bringing it to a height of 1,046 feet, 46 feet taller than the originally announced height of the Empire State Building.
Al Smith realized that he was close to losing the title of world’s tallest building, and on December 11, 1929, he announced that the Empire State would now reach the height of 1,250 feet. He would add a top or a hat to the building that would be even more distinctive than any other building in the city. John Tauranac describes the plan:
[The top of the Empire State Building] would be more than ornamental, more than a spire or dome or a pyramid put there to add a desired few feet to the height of the building or to mask something as mundane as a water tank. Their top, they said, would serve a higher calling. The Empire State Building would be equipped for an age of transportation that was then only the dream of aviation pioneers.
This dream of the aviation pioneers was travel by dirigible, or zeppelin, and the Empire State Building was going to have a mooring mast at its top for docking these new airships, which would accommodate passengers on already existing transatlantic routes and new routes that were yet to come.
The Age of Dirigibles
By the 1920s, dirigibles were being hailed as the transportation of the future. Also known today as blimps, dirigibles were actually enormous steel-framed balloons, with envelopes of cotton fabric filled with hydrogen and helium to make them lighter than air. Unlike a balloon, a dirigible could be maneuvered by the use of propellers and rudders, and passengers could ride in the gondola, or enclosed compartment, under the balloon.
Dirigibles had a top speed of eighty miles per hour, and they could cruise at seventy miles per hour for thousands of miles without needing refueling. Some were as long as one thousand feet, the same length as four blocks in New York City. The one obstacle to their expanded use in New York City was the lack of a suitable landing area. Al Smith saw an opportunity for his Empire State Building: A mooring mast added to the top of the building would allow dirigibles to anchor there for several hours for refueling or service, and to let passengers off and on. Dirigibles were docked by means of an electric winch, which hauled in a line from the front of the ship and then tied it to a mast. The body of the dirigible could swing in the breeze, and yet passengers could safely get on and off the dirigible by walking down a gangplank to an open observation platform.
The architects and engineers of the Empire State Building consulted with experts, taking tours of the equipment and mooring operations at the U.S. Naval Air Station in Lakehurst, New Jersey. The navy was the leader in the research and development of dirigibles in the United States. The navy even offered its dirigible, the Los Angeles, to be used in testing the mast. The architects also met with the president of a recently formed airship transport company that planned to offer dirigible service across the Pacific Ocean.
When asked about the mooring mast, Al Smith commented:
[It’s] on the level, all right. No kidding. We’re working on the thing now. One set of engineers here in New York is trying to dope out a practical, workable arrangement and the Government people in Washington are figuring on some safe way of mooring airships to this mast.
Designing the Mast
The architects could not simply drop a mooring mast on top of the Empire State Building’s flat roof. A thousand-foot dirigible moored at the top of the building, held by a single cable tether, would add stress to the building’s frame. The stress of the dirigible’s load and the wind pressure would have to be transmitted all the way to the building’s foundation, which was nearly eleven hundred feet below. The steel frame of the Empire State Building would have to be modified and strengthened to accommodate this new situation. Over sixty thousand dollars’ worth of modifications had to be made to the building’s framework.
Rather than building a utilitarian mast without any ornamentation, the architects designed a shiny glass and chrome-nickel stainless steel tower that would be illuminated from inside, with a stepped-back design that imitated the overall shape of the building itself. The rocket-shaped mast would have four wings at its corners, of shiny aluminum, and would rise to a conical roof that would house the mooring arm. The winches and control machinery for the dirigible mooring would be housed in the base of the shaft itself, which also housed elevators and stairs to bring passengers down to the eighty-sixth floor, where baggage and ticket areas would be located.
The building would now be 102 floors, with a glassed-in observation area on the 101st floor and an open observation platform on the 102nd floor. This observation area was to double as the boarding area for dirigible passengers.
Once the architects had designed the mooring mast and made changes to the existing plans for the building’s skeleton, construction proceeded as planned. When the building had been framed to the 85th floor, the roof had to be completed before the framing for the mooring mast could take place. The mast also had a skeleton of steel and was clad in stainless steel with glass windows. Two months after the workers celebrated framing the entire building, they were back to raise an American flag again—this time at the top of the frame for the mooring mast.
The Fate of the Mast
The mooring mast of the Empire State Building was destined to never fulfill its purpose, for reasons that should have been apparent before it was ever constructed. The greatest reason was one of safety: Most dirigibles from outside of the United States used hydrogen rather than helium, and hydrogen is highly flammable. When the German dirigible Hindenburg was destroyed by fire in Lakehurst, New Jersey, on May 6, 1937, the owners of the Empire State Building realized how much worse that accident could have been if it had taken place above a densely populated area such as downtown New York.
The greatest obstacle to the successful use of the mooring mast was nature itself. The winds on top of the building were constantly shifting due to violent air currents. Even if the dirigible were tethered to the mooring mast, the back of the ship would swivel around and around the mooring mast. In December 1930, the U.S. Navy dirigible Los Angeles approached the mooring mast but could not get close enough to tie up because of forceful winds. Fearing that the wind would blow the dirigible onto the sharp spires of other buildings in the area, which would puncture the dirigible’s shell, the captain could not even take his hands off the control levers. 
Two weeks later, another dirigible, the Goodyear blimp Columbia, attempted a publicity stunt where it would tie up and deliver a bundle of newspapers to the Empire State Building. Because the complete dirigible mooring equipment had never been installed, a worker atop the mooring mast would have to catch the bundle of papers on a rope dangling from the blimp. The papers were delivered in this fashion, but after this stunt the idea of using the mooring mast was shelved. In February 1931, Irving Clavan of the building’s architectural office said, “The as yet unsolved problems of mooring air ships to a fixed mast at such a height made it desirable to postpone to a later date the final installation of the landing gear.”

The rooms in the Empire State Building that had been set aside for the ticketing and baggage of dirigible passengers were made over into the world’s highest soda fountain and tea garden for use by the sightseers who flocked to the observation decks.
